sections.name: Election Reform in Lowell
sections.content:
In 2019, all eyes are on Lowell, Massachusetts. The City of Lowell’s at-large electoral system has been challenged in a recent lawsuit (Huot et al. v. City of Lowell et al). Plaintiffs in the case argued that the current system dilutes the votes of Lowell's communities of color for the City Council and School Board. For more information about the lawsuit, read LCR's explainer [here].

This November, Lowell residents will have a chance to vote on a new system! The choices for City Council are (a) a city-wide system electing 9 council members by ranked choice, or (b) 8 districts plus 3 at-large seats, raising the size of the council to 11 members.

Read our public report on the choice facing Lowell voters this November! We explain the options on the ballot and some general differences between systems of election. For more technical explanations of our modeling, refer to our detailed report.

Versions of the public report are also available in Spanish, Portuguese, and Cambodian Khmer.

sections.name: See randomly constructed plans
sections.disc: Click on any of the districting plans below to open it in Districtr. Then feel free to start modifying it yourself! Each of these plans was generated by randomized algorithms, while making sure that the Asian and Latino communities meet the statistical thresholds laid out in the legal requirements, where applicable.

plans.title: Sample valid 8-district plans (Option on the Ballot)

sections.name: Why?
sections.content: These modules were created to aid in a paper, "Locating the representational baseline: Republicans in Massachusetts," written by MGGG and collaborators. Despite Republicans usually gaining between 30% and 40% of the two-way vote share in statewide elections, Massachusetts has not elected a Republican to the US House of Representatives since 1994. The paper finds that the underperformance of Republicans in Massachusetts is not the result of gerrymandering or candidate availability, but rather is a factor of the spatial distribution of Republican voters in the state.

sections.name: About the data
sections.content:
The units you see here are precincts from the 2000 redistricting cycle, precincts from the 2010 redistricting cycle, and Massachusetts' towns and municipalities

The 2002-2010 raw, unprocessed shapefile comes from the United States Census Bureau and was sent to MGGG by Secretary of the Commonwealth Francis Galvin's office. The 2012-2016 raw, unprocessed precinct shapefile comes from the office of the Secretary of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, William Francis Galvin. The town shapefile was downloaded from the Massachusetts Bureau of Geographic Information website. All election data comes from the Secretary of the Commonwealth's Elections Division website.

The source precinct shapefiles for these modules, along with additional information about processing, is available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @mggg-states.

sections.name: About the data
sections.content: The units you see here are census blocks. Data for this module were obtained from the US Census Bureau. The block shapefile for the City of Lowell was downloaded from the Census TIGER/Line Shapefiles. Demographic information from the 2010 Decennial Census was downloaded at the block level from American FactFinder. The source shapefile with demographic information is available for download from MGGG's GitHub organization @gerrymandr.

sections.name: Districts in Oregon
sections.content: Oregon currently has 5 Congressional seats. The Oregon Legislative Assembly has 30 members in the State Senate, and 60 members in the State House, where each representative is elected from a single member districts. Additionally in Oregon, Legislative Assembly districts are nested, where each Senate districts is comprised of two adjacent House districts.

sections.name: Portland City Council
sections.content: The City Council in Portland currently consists of 5 members (including the mayor). City council members (commissioners) are elected at-large in nonpartisan elections.

sections.name: Redistricting Rules
sections.content:
Like all states in the US, Oregon must comply with Constitutional equal population requirements and the Voting Rights Act. Oregon State Assembly districts are required to nest, meaning that each State Senate district is comprised to two adjacent State House districts. In addition, Oregon Law, asks that districts should "as nearly as practicable" meet the following criteria:

  • Districts must be contiguous.
  • Districts should utilize existing geographic or political boundaries.
  • Districts should not divide communities of common interest.
  • Districts should be connected by transportation links.
  • Districts must not be drawn for the purpose of favoring a political party, incumbent, or other person.
Currently in Oregon districts are drawn by the State Legislature and subject to veto by the governor.

sections.name: About the Data
sections.content:
The units in these modules are precincts.

This shapefile was compiled by Kevin Rancik with the help of Steve Gerontakis and was used by The Oregonian. It was processed and verified by members of the Metric Geometry and Gerrymandering Group.

The Oregon precinct shapefile was obtained from Kevin Rancik's personal website. Rancik and Gerontakis obtained the raw county-level precinct boundaries from local county elections offices and county clerks, documented in detail here. Election results for 2016 and 2018 were obtained from the MIT Election Data and Science Lab (MEDSL). 2010 Decennial Census demographic data were downloaded from the Census API. The 2010 census block shapefile for Oregon along with congressional and state legislative districts were downloaded from the US Census Bureau’s TIGER/Line Shapefiles.

Precinct election returns were cleaned by MGGG staff in order to join them to the precinct shapefile. Certain precincts in the shapefile and in the results were merged in order to reconcile discrepencies. Demographic data was aggregated from the block level using MGGG’s proration software. Congressional and state legislative district IDs were assigned to precincts also using this package.

sections.name: Explore the currently enacted plans
sections.disc: Click on any of the districting plans below to open it in Districtr. Then feel free to start modifying it yourself!

sections.name: Election Reform in Oregon
sections.content: People not Politicians filled Ballot Measures in Oregon that would create an independent citizen redistricting commission if passed in November 2020.
